content: International esports organization The **Global Esports Federation** (**GEF**) is a non-governmental organization that convenes the world's [esports](/wiki/Esports) (or competitive [video gaming](/wiki/Video_game)) community. It was established on December 16, 2019, and is headquartered in Singapore, where it is a registered society under the Singapore Registry of Societies. The GEF consists of 180 Member Federations and four continental Esports Development Federations (Africa, Europe, Oceania and Pan Am). As of January 2025, there are 10 Commissions and two Councils that guide the work of the federation. The founding President of the GEF was [Chris Chan](/wiki/Chris_Chan) of Singapore. As of September 2025, Paul J. Foster, KStJH, who also serves as CEO, was formally elected President, having previously assumed the role of President ad interim following Chan's resignation in July 2025. The organization's flagship event is the annual Global Esports Games (GEG), held since 2021. The GEG is a multi-title esports competition featuring athletes from Member Federations that takes place in December every year. The GEF also organizes the Global Esports Tour (GET) and supports its Member Federations in hosting local esports competitions and regional qualifying events. ## History The GEF was launched on December 16, 2019 with [Chris Chan](/wiki/Chris_Chan) appointed as its founding President. The Board currently consists of a President, six Vice-Presidents, and 15 Board Members. The GEF appointed its first Chief Executive Officer & Secretary General, Sir Paul J. Foster, in March 2021. Chan was re-elected as President of GEF in 2023 for a second four-year term. On 23 July 2025, following Chan's resignation, Foster was elected President ad interim by the GEF Executive Committee, and formally elected President at its Board Meeting in September 2025. The GEF organizes two main events: the Global Esports Games (GEG) and the Global Esports Tour (GET). The inaugural Global Esports Games were staged in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) in December 2021, followed by the second edition in [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul), Turkey in 2022 and [Riyadh](/wiki/Riyadh), Saudi Arabia in 2023. The first season of the Global Esports Tour was staged in 2021, beginning in [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles) in September. Both the GEG and GET are held on an annual basis. ## GEF Board DesignationNameCountry/TerritoryPresidentPaul J. In 2023, the Oceania and Europe Esports Development Federations were formed to continue the support of sustainable development of esports communities throughout the world. ## Events ### Global Esports Games The Global Esports Games (GEG) is a multi-title esports competition featuring athletes from Member Federations that takes place in December every year. In May 2021, the GEF announced the host cities for the first three editions of the GEG. The inaugural GEG took place in Singapore in 2021, followed by Istanbul in 2022 and Riyadh in 2023. The 2023 edition was the largest held to date, with 950 athletes competing from more than 100 countries. Global Esports Games 2025 will take place in Mumbai in February 2026 and the 2026 edition will be held in Los Angeles in December 2026. A variety of esports titles have been contested at the Global Esports Games, including: [Valve](/wiki/Valve_Corporation)’s [Dota 2](/wiki/Dota_2), [Konami](/wiki/Konami)’s [eFootball PES 2021 Season Update](/wiki/EFootball_PES_2021_Season_Update), [eFootball 2023](/wiki/EFootball_2023) and [eFootball 2024](/wiki/EFootball_2024), [Capcom](/wiki/Capcom)’s [Street Fighter V](/wiki/Street_Fighter_V) and [Street Fighter 6](/wiki/Street_Fighter_6), as well as [Krafton](/wiki/Krafton)'s [PUBG Mobile](/wiki/PUBG_Mobile). Competition categories include Open and Women, with the Open category allowing both men and women to compete together. #### Editions Source: LocationDatesEvent nameTitlesCategoryChampionPlayers 2–10, 2026Global Esports Games 2026TBC ### Global Esports Tour The Global Esports Tour (GET) is a series of tournaments for professional esports athletes and teams. In September 2021, the GEF announced the first series of the GET, with each stage showcasing a different esports title. The first edition of the GET had a total prize pool of US$500,000. - [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles), [United States of America](/wiki/United_States): September 27–28 - [Hearthstone](/wiki/Hearthstone) - [Riyadh](/wiki/Riyadh), [Saudi Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia): October 21–23 - [PUBG Mobile](/wiki/PUBG_Mobile) - [Dubai](/wiki/Dubai), [United Arab Emirates](/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates): November 26–27 - Counter-strike: Global Offensive In 2022, the second season of the GET was held over two stages in the cities of Dubai and Riyadh. Dubai staged a CS:GO tournament from June 10–11. Riyadh held a [Street Fighter V - Champion Edition](/wiki/Street_Fighter_V_Champion_Edition) tournament from July 25–27 during the annual Gamers8 festival. In 2023, the third season of the GET was staged in Riyadh from August 26–27 during Gamers8 festival. Participating pro athletes competed for a US$50,000 prize pool in eFootball 2023. In 2024, Season 4 of the Global Esports Tour headed to [Rio de Janeiro, Brazil](/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro) with a [Counter-Strike 2](/wiki/Counter-Strike_2) tournament from April 18–21. In 2025, Season 5 of the Global Esports Tour announced cities including Mumbai, India, and Lima, Peru, for the first time. ### Marquee Events Beginning in 2021, the Global Esports Federation began hosting esports championships at regional and continental Games. The first marquee event, named the [Commonwealth Esports Championships](/wiki/Commonwealth_Esports_Championships), was held at the [Birmingham 2022 Commonwealth Games](/wiki/2022_Commonwealth_Games). The South American Esports Championships was held in collaboration with the [South American Sports Organization](/wiki/ODESUR) (ODESUR) at the [Asuncion 2022 South American Games](/wiki/2022_South_American_Games). The 2023 European Games Esports Championships was held alongside the [Kraków-Małopolska 2023 European Games](/wiki/2023_European_Games) with support from the [European Olympic Committees](/wiki/European_Olympic_Committees) (EOC). The 2023 Pan American Esports Championships was held in Santiago, Chile in parallel with the [Santiago 2023 Pan American Games](/wiki/2023_Pan_American_Games) in collaboration with [Panam Sports](/wiki/Panam_Sports). ## Partners [Tencent](/wiki/Tencent) is a Founding Global Partner of the GEF. The federation also has a list of other strategic partners including an agreement signed with [Amazon MGM Studios](/wiki/Amazon_MGM_Studios) in January 2024, as well as with the [International Telecommunication Union](/wiki/International_Telecommunication_Union), [Peace and Sport](/wiki/Peace_and_Sport) and [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO), among others. The federation announced a partnership with the [Los Angeles Times Media Group](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times). The GEF also has several key partners within the Olympic Movement, including the [Commonwealth Games Federation](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games_Federation) (CGF), [Pan American Sports Organization](/wiki/Panam_Sports) (Panam Sports), [Olympic Council of Asia](/wiki/Olympic_Council_of_Asia) (OCA), [European Olympic Committees](/wiki/European_Olympic_Committees) (EOC), [South American Sports Organization](/wiki/ODESUR) (ODESUR), and [Centro Caribe Sports](/wiki/Centro_Caribe_Sports). - [International Esports Federation](/wiki/International_Esports_Federation) - Global Esports Federation - Singapore 2021 Global Esports Games - Istanbul 2022 Global Esports Games - Riyadh 2023 Global Esports Games
title: Global Esports Federation
